Tomato.description: A red fruit rich in lycopene and vitamin C.
tip: Eat raw for maximum vitamin C
risk: Avoid metal containers for long storage
Tomato.meal_prep_solution: Store at room temperature for 2-3 days, refrigerate when ripe
Tomato.random_fact: Tomatoes are technically a fruit, but they are commonly used as vegetables.

Lettuce.description: A leafy green vegetable commonly used in salads.
tip: Wash right before eating to avoid wilting
Store in the fridge for freshness
risk: Can spoil quickly if not properly stored
Lettuce.meal_prep_solution: Store in the fridge for up to 3 days in a sealed container
Lettuce.random_fact: Lettuce was first cultivated by the ancient Egyptians.

Mushroom.description: A type of fungi commonly used in cooking, rich in nutrients.
tip: Store in a paper bag to prevent moisture buildup
risk: Not good for reheating, should be consumed as soon as cooked
Mushroom.meal_prep_solution: Keep in the fridge for up to 3 days, store in a paper bag for moisture control
Mushroom.random_fact: Mushrooms can produce vitamin D when exposed to sunlight.

Bell Pepper.description: A colorful vegetable rich in vitamin C and antioxidants.
tip: Eat raw for maximum vitamin C, or roast to enhance flavor
risk: Avoid overcooking as it may lose nutrients
Bell Pepper.meal_prep_solution: Store in the fridge for up to 5-7 days
Bell Pepper.random_fact: Red bell peppers are fully ripened versions of green peppers.

Natto.description: A fermented soybean product, rich in probiotics and vitamin K2.
tip: Best eaten raw to preserve probiotics
risk: Not suitable for people with soy allergies
Natto.meal_prep_solution: Store in the fridge for up to 7 days or freeze for longer storage
Natto.random_fact: Natto contains nattokinase, an enzyme believed to help with blood circulation.
